title: Pre-Norman Ownership
description: Before the Norman Conquest, the Ilmer estate was held by Godwin, a supporter of Earl Lewin, who had the legal right to sell it.

title: Norman Survey (Domesday Book)
description: The manor is recorded as belonging to the powerful Odo, Bishop of Bayeux, and is managed by his tenant, Robert. Its taxable value is £4.

title: Church Patronage Granted
description: The right to appoint the priest (the advowson) of Ilmer Church is granted to the Nunnery of Stodeley (aka Studley Priory) in Oxfordshire.
references: Dunkin's History of Bullington and Ploughley Hundred, p. 133

title: Royal Charter for Falconry Duty
description: King John issues a charter confirming the royal duty of Keeper of the King's Hawks to Thomas Fitz-Bernard and his heirs.
references: Rymer's Fædera, new Edition, Vol. 1, p. 90

title: Manor Claim Settled
description: A legal claim to half the manor by other descendants of the Romenel family is settled, securing the title for Albreda de Jarponville.

title: Church Grant Confirmed
description: A legal agreement (a fine) is made between Ralph Fitz-Bernard and the Prioress of Stodeley, further securing the nunnery's rights to the church.

title: Church Income Reassigned
description: The church's main income (the rectory) is formally assigned to the Nuns of Stodeley, who in return must provide a vicar for the parish.
references: Fine Rolls for Buckinghamshire, 14 Henry III, nos. 87, 98

title: Land Held by Royal Service
description: Ilmer is mentioned in the Hundred Rolls (Rotuli Hundredorum) as being held by John son of Bernard by serjeanty, a form of land tenure requiring personal service to the king, which in this case was the keeping of his goshawks.

title: Death of John Fitz-Bernard
description: The lord of the manor, John Fitz-Bernard, dies. Guardianship of his heir is granted to Imbert de Puges.

title: New Vicar Appointed
description: Walter de Ilmere is appointed as the new vicar by Elizabeth, Prioress of Stodley.

title: Death of Vicar Walter
description: Walter, the Vicar of Ilmer who had been appointed by the Prioress of Stodeley, dies.

title: Land Granted to Stodley Priory
description: The Hundred Rolls record that Albreda de Jarpanwile, aunt of the manor's holder, gave one virgate of land (approximately 30 acres) in Ilmer in 'pure alms' to the Prioress of Stodley.

title: Church Valued for Papal Taxation
description: The Taxatio Ecclesiastica, a survey ordered by Pope Nicholas IV, assessed the Church of Ilmere at £4 6s 8d and the vicarage at £1 13s 4d, for a total tax assessment of £6.
references: Taxatio Ecclesiastica of Pope Nicholas IV, 1291-92

title: Death of Ralph Fitz-Bernard
description: Ralph Fitz-Bernard dies while holding the title to the manor of Ilmer.

title: Manor Sold to Blacket
description: Thomas Fitz-Bernard sells the estate to John Blacket.
references: Willis's Manuscripts, Bodleian Library, Vol. 16, p. 120

title: Poverty Assessment
description: During the reign of Edward III, a tax report confirms that the residents of Ilmer were too poor to properly farm the land.

title: Death of John Blacket
description: The new owner of the manor, John Blacket, dies.

title: Manor Sold to de Molyns
description: John Blacket the elder sells the Ilmer estate to the powerful and influential Sir John de Molyns.

title: Private Park Created
description: Sir John de Molyns receives a royal license from Edward III to enclose his woods at Ilmer, creating a private hunting park.
references: Dugdale's Baronage of England, Vol. 2, p. 145

title: Feudal Privileges Granted
description: Sir John de Molyns is granted exclusive hunting rights (known as 'free warren') and other valuable feudal privileges for his estates.

title: Ilmer Custumal Recorded
description: An Ilmer Custumal was recorded.

title: Manor Held in Serjeanty
description: Sir John Moleyns of Stoke Poges held the manor of Ilmer in serjeanty as keeper of the king's hawks.

title: Manor Seized by the King
description: After Sir John de Molyns falls from royal favour, his extensive properties, including the manor of Ilmer, are seized by the Crown.

title: Manor Restored
description: The manor is returned to Sir John de Molyns, along with a new charter confirming his ownership and the royal services attached to it.

title: Legal Claim Dropped
description: Isabella, daughter of a previous owner, formally gives up any legal claim she might have had to the manor of Ilmer.

title: New Vicar Appointed
description: John de Horwood is appointed as the new vicar by Margery, the Prioress of Stodley.

title: Vicar Granted Land
description: Sir Richard Gladewyne, vicar, was granted a plot 100ft x 50ft, facing east by John de Molyns. An additional grant of 2 plots totalling 7.5 acres was also made.
references: Calendar of Close Roles of Edward iii, 1349

title: Vicar Richard Gladwin Resigns
description: Richard Gladwin resigns from his position as Vicar of Ilmer.

title: Manor Seized Again
description: The manor is seized by the Crown once more after Sir John de Molyns fails to appear in court. It is then transferred to his son, William.
references: Abbreviation of the Originalia Rolls, Vol. 2, p. 255

title: Death of Sir John Molines
description: Sir John Molines dies.
references: Stoke Poges, a concise account of the church and manor, and also of the poet, Thomas Gray, 1896

title: Death of Lady Egidia de Moleyns
description: Lady Egidia (aka Gilles de Moleyns), widow of Sir John Molines, dies, and the Ilmer property passes to her son, Sir William Molines.
references: Stoke Poges, a concise account of the church and manor, and also of the poet, Thomas Gray, 1896
Dugdale's Baronage of England, Vol. 2, p. 147

title: Property Descends to Sir Richard Molines
description: Ilmer property descends to Sir Richard Molines.
references: Stoke Poges, a concise account of the church and manor, and also of the poet, Thomas Gray, 1896

title: New Vicar Appointed by Exchange
description: John Jonason becomes the new vicar after exchanging his previous position with the former vicar, Robert Burkard.

title: New Vicar Appointed
description: Thomas Haddon is appointed as vicar by Elizabeth Freemantle, the Prioress of Stodley.

title: New Vicar Appointed After Resignation
description: Following the resignation of Thomas Haddon, Robert Green is appointed as the new vicar.

title: New Vicar Appointed After Resignation
description: After Robert Green resigns, John Chicheley is appointed as the new vicar.

title: New Vicar Appointed After Resignation
description: Following the resignation of John Chicheley, John Ayliffe is appointed as the new vicar.

title: Royal Service Defined
description: The specific duty for holding the manor is defined as feeding the King's falcons and presenting one sparrow-hawk to the King each year.
references: Lipscomb's History... (see Stoke Poges and Brill, p. 99)

title: New Vicar Appointed by Exchange
description: John Barre becomes vicar of Ilmer after exchanging positions with the previous vicar, John Crook.

title: New Vicar Formally Admitted
description: William Gibbes is formally admitted as the Vicar of Ilmer.

title: Hungerford Family Inherits Manor
description: The manor passes to the Hungerford family through the marriage of the Molyns heiress, Alianore, to Robert Hungerford.

title: New Vicar Appointed
description: Thomas Spencer is appointed as vicar by the Convent of Studley.

title: New Vicar Appointed
description: John Seler is appointed as the new vicar.

title: Death of Vicar Howes
description: Thomas (or John) Howes, who had been vicar since at least 1447, dies.

title: New Vicar Appointed
description: John Bennet is appointed as vicar by the Convent of Studley.

title: Lands Forfeited During Wars of the Roses
description: As a Lancastrian supporter, Robert Hungerford is declared a traitor by Parliament, and all his lands are forfeited to the Crown.

title: New Vicar Appointed
description: Henry Stodysbury is appointed as the new vicar.

title: Vicar Robert Byrcham Resigns
description: Robert Byrcham resigns his position as vicar.

title: New Vicar Appointed After Resignation
description: Following the resignation of Henry Stodysbury, John Sunday is appointed as the new vicar.

title: Property Sales During Forfeiture
description: A legal transaction (a fine) is recorded for Ilmer and other manors, suggesting parts of the estate were sold off while seized by the Crown.

title: New Vicar Appointed After Resignation
description: After John Sunday resigns, Robert Richardson is appointed as the new vicar.

title: New Vicar Appointed After Resignation
description: Richard ap Jenner is appointed vicar after Robert Richardson resigns in his favour.

title: Lands Restored to Family
description: When King Henry VII takes the throne, the treason charge against the Hungerford family is reversed, and their lands are returned.

title: First Bell Cast
description: The first of the three church bells was cast. It is inscribed Sancta Margareta ora pro nobis. Between 1494-1509, William Hasylwood, the likely founder of this bell, wass active as a bell caster at his foundry in Reading
references: The church bells of Buckinghamshire, Cocks, 1897

title: New Vicar Appointed
description: James Withington is appointed as vicar by the Prioress of Studley.

title: Death of Vicar Taylor
description: John Taylor, the Vicar of Ilmer, dies.

title: Church Surveyed for Royal Taxation
description: During the Reformation, the General Ecclesiastical Survey (Valor Ecclesiasticus) was conducted to determine taxes payable to Henry VIII instead of the Pope. It recorded the annual deductions for the Ilmer rectory pension at 6 shillings 8 pence, with a free rent of 2 pence.

title: Church Property Granted After Dissolution
description: Following the Dissolution of the Monasteries, King Henry VIII grants the church property and its income (the Rectory) to John Croke of Chilton.

title: Church Advowson Granted to John Croke
description: The Church Advowson was granted to John Croke of Studley by Henry VIII following the dissolution of the monasteries.
references: The Grant of the Priory of Studley &c, translated into English, 1617

title: Death of Earl of Huntingdon
description: George, Earl of Huntingdon, dies. His family had acquired the manor by marrying the Hungerford heiress.

title: Will of John Godwyn
description: The will of John Godwyn of Ilmere is recorded.

title: Death of Sir Robert Dormer
description: Sir Robert Dormer died.

title: Edwardian Inventory of Church
description: An inventory of Ilmer church mentioned Edmund Godwyn and Wylliam Mede. It reported the church included two further bells - a handbell and a Saunse bell, which would have been located outside the church on the Western gable

title: Dormer Family Acquires Manor
description: The manor is now owned by the Dormer family. A royal inquiry confirms that William Dormer holds the title to Ilmer.

title: Vicar Prepares Will
description: Vicar James Withington writes his will, requesting to be buried in Ilmer church.

title: New Vicar Appointed
description: John Swainson is appointed as vicar by the lord of the manor, Sir Robert Dormer.

title: Death of Vicar Palmer
description: John Palmer, the Vicar of Ilmer, dies.

title: Vicar Prepares Will
description: Vicar John Swainson writes his will, asking to be buried in the chancel of Ilmer church.

title: Death of William Dormer
description: William Dormer, lord of the manor, dies and is succeeded by his son, Robert.

title: Crown Sells Off Former Church Lands
description: Queen Elizabeth I grants small parcels of land, originally given to fund lights in the church, to new owners.

title: Second Bell Cast
description: The second of the church bells was cast. It is inscribed Gloria in excelcuc (sic) deo 1586.

title: Crown Sells More Church Land
description: The Queen grants another two and a half acres of former church land to new owners.

title: Robert Dormer Knighted
description: Robert Dormer, the lord of the manor, is knighted by the Queen.

title: Parish Taxed for Royal Household
description: Ilmer is taxed to provide beef and mutton for Queen Elizabeth I's household.

title: New Vicar Appointed
description: Thomas Vandrey is appointed as the new vicar by Sir Robert Dormer.

title: Robert Dormer Becomes a Baronet
description: Sir Robert Dormer is elevated to the rank of Baronet.

title: Robert Dormer Becomes a Baron
description: Shortly after, Sir Robert Dormer is ennobled, becoming Baron Dormer of Wenge.

title: Death of Baron Dormer
description: Baron Dormer, who as lord of the manor was also the King's Master Falconer, dies.

title: Third Bell Cast
description: The third of the church bells was cast. It is inscribed Henri Knight made mee ano 1618.

title: Steeple Reported in Need of Repair
description: Bishop Williams of Lincoln reported that 'The steeple to be repaired in the whole'. By the 19th century, the church had no steeple. It is not known when or why it was removed.
references: The church bells of Buckinghamshire : their inscriptions, founders, uses and traditions, 1897

title: Death of Robert Dormer, 1st Earl of Carnarvon
description: Robert Dormer, 1st Earl of Carnarvon, died in Ascott House, Wing.

title: Death of John Hampden
description: John Hampden died in Thame aged 48. His body was buried on June 25th at Great Hampden. Some speculate that the funeral procession may have passed through Ilmer.

title: Vicar Ejected During Civil War
description: Vicar Thomas Vandrey is removed from his position, likely due to his royalist sympathies during the English Civil War.

title: New Minister Appointed by Parliament
description: Thomas Lillington is appointed to the position after its income was seized by Parliament (a process called sequestration).

title: Survey of Glebe Land
description: A survey of the glebe land (church land) of Ilmer was conducted.

title: Parish Farmland Enclosed
description: The traditional open-field farming system in Ilmer is ended as the entire parish is enclosed into private fields.

title: Church Aisle Demolished
description: Permission is granted to tear down a side aisle or vestry of the church and use the materials for repairs. The aisle is never rebuilt.

title: Licence to Remove Church Vestry
description: A licence was granted to remove the church vestry on the south side.

title: Quaker Meetings Hosted
description: Thomas Saunders hosted Quaker meetings at his house in Ilmer.
references: Memories of Jordans and the Chalfonts

title: William Lillingston Becomes Vicar
description: William Lillingston became vicar of Ilmer.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: Death of Elizabeth Stanhope, Countess of Chesterfield
description: Elizabeth Stanhope, Countess of Chesterfield, daughter of Charles Dormer, died aged 23.

title: New Vicar Appointed
description: John Lillingston is appointed as the new vicar by Charles Dormer, Earl of Carnarvon.

title: Marriage of Damaris Saunders
description: Damaris, daughter of Thomas Saunders, was to marry John Kirton of Hammersmith.
references: Thomas Ellwood's place, Quaker minute book

title: Curate Licensed
description: William Lillingston, the vicar's son, is officially licensed to serve as the assistant priest (Curate) in Ilmer.

title: Edward Gomme Leases Land
description: Edward Gomme leased land in Ilmer from Edward Saunders of Bledlow.

title: Falconry Claim Denied at Coronation
description: At the coronation of King James II, Charles Dormer, 2nd Earl of Carnarvon claim to the hereditary role of Marshall, Surveyor and Conservator of His Majesties Hawks in England is denied. The role was held due to his holding of the Manor of Ilmer.
references: Sandford's History and Account of Claims, p. 16
History of the coronation of James II, Sandford, 1687

title: Marcus Parker Becomes Vicar
description: Marcus Parker became [vicar of Ilmer](https://theclergydatabase.org.uk/jsp/persons/DisplayCcePerson.jsp?PersonID=86069). Lipscomb calls the new vicar 'Matthew Palmer', believed to be in error.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: Highway Repair Indictment Discharged
description: Ilmer inhabitants were discharged from an indictment after repairing the highway from Bicester to Wycombe through Ilmer.

title: Charles Cornish Becomes Vicar
description: Charles Cornish is appointed vicar. He later resigns after being offered a church position in Wales.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982
Lipscomb's History... (see Risborough & Pedigree of Carter, p. 135)

title: Death of Former Vicar Palmer
description: Matthew Palmer, a former vicar of Ilmer, is buried at the nearby parish of Dinton.

title: Manor Passes to Stanhope Family
description: [Charles Dormer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Dormer,_2nd_Earl_of_Carnarvon), 2nd Earl of Carnarvon died with no surviving sons, passing the Dormer lands to his eldest grandson via his daughter Elizabeth and her husband, Philip Stanhope, Earl of Chesterfield
references: Lipscomb's History... (see Pedigree of Stanhope under Eythrop)

title: Death of Philip Stanhope, 2nd Earl of Chesterfield
description: [Philip Stanhope](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philip_Stanhope,_2nd_Earl_of_Chesterfield), 2nd Earl of Chesterfield, widower of Elizabeth Dormer, died.

title: Inhabitants Cited for Unrepaired Highways
description: The inhabitants of Ilmer were cited for not repairing the highways, which were in a 'ruinous and bad condition'.

title: Henry Stanbridge Becomes Vicar
description: Henry Stanbridge became vicar of Ilmer.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: New Vicar Appointed
description: Henry Stanbridge is appointed as the new vicar by William Stanhope, Esq.

title: Inhabitants Cited Again for Unrepaired Highways
description: The inhabitants of Ilmer were cited for not repairing the highways.

title: Death of Philip Stanhope, 3rd Earl of Chesterfield
description: Philip Stanhope, 3rd Earl of Chesterfield died.

title: Small Tithes Dispute
description: An order for William Bowden of Ilmer to pay John Grace of Princes Risborough for two years' small tithes of wool and lamb was quashed.

title: New Vicar Inducted
description: James Andrew formally takes up his position as the new vicar.

title: James Andrew Becomes Vicar
description: James Andrew became vicar of Ilmer.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: Death of Vicar Stanbridge
description: Henry Stanbridge, the Vicar of Ilmer, dies.

title: Change of calendar
description: The UK changed from the Julian calendar to the Gregorian calendar.

title: Death of Philip Stanhope, 4th Earl of Chesterfield
description: Philip Stanhope, 4th Earl of Chesterfield died. He adopted his cousin and godson who became the 5th Earl and inherited the 'Dormer Lands', including Ilmer. Philip became famous for his 400 '[letters to his son](https://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/3351)' over 30 years, subtitled, the Fine Art of becoming a MAN OF THE WORLD and a GENTLEMAN. Philip wrote the letters to his illegitimate son which were published by his son's widow to fund her pension.

title: Poor Relief Costs Recorded
description: The annual cost of supporting the parish's poor is recorded as £47 12s.

title: Survey of Stanhope Family Estates
description: A survey of the Buckinghamshire estates of the Stanhope family (Earls of Chesterfield) was conducted.

title: Poor Relief Costs Drop
description: The cost of supporting the parish's poor drops significantly to £28.

title: Thomas Jones Becomes Vicar
description: Thomas Jones became vicar of Ilmer.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: Farm Occupied by Thomas Kingham for Sale
description: A farm in the occupation of Thomas Kingham was put up for sale.

title: Lease Agreements Mention Farms
description: Lease agreements with Lord Chesterfield mentioned Lower Farm, Middle Farm, and 'Coal Harbour' Farm.
references: the W.H.Smith estate papers, Reading University

title: Population Recorded
description: The population of Ilmer was 74, with 13 inhabited houses and 13 families.

title: Ilmer Manor for Auction
description: Ilmer Manor, consisting of dairy farms of 463 acres, was to be sold at auction.

title: Ilmer Manor Sold to Joseph Franklin
description: Ilmer Manor was sold to Joseph Franklin.
references: Bucks Archives, Records of the Buckinghamshire estates of the Stanhope family

title: Vicarage Income Recorded
description: The vicar's annual income from church lands and tithe compositions is reported as £72.

title: Deed of Lower Farm
description: A deed for Lower Farm, Ilmer, was recorded.

title: Death of Philip Stanhope, 5th Earl of Chesterfield
description: Philip Stanhope, 5th Earl of Chesterfield died.

title: Vicarage Income Increases
description: The vicar's annual income is reported to have increased to £97.

title: Moreton John Edward Frewen Admitted to Gray's Inn
description: Moreton John Edward Frewen was admitted to Gray's Inn.
references: Register of Admissions to Gray's Inn, 1889

title: Parish Census
description: The national census records that Ilmer contains only 12 houses and a total population of 68 people.

title: Population Recorded
description: The population was 68 (of which 40 were female) in 12 houses.

title: Ilmer Manor and Dairy Farms for Sale
description: Ilmer Manor and dairy farms were put up for sale, with farms occupied by Abraham Eyre, John West, A Wooster, John Tappin, and John Gomme.

title: Population Grows
description: The population of the parish has grown to 75 residents.

title: Bastardy Case
description: William Stratford was noted as the father of the female bastard child of Rebecca Rutland of Stoke Mandeville and was ordered to pay 1s6d per week.
references: Aylesbury petty sessions, bastardy cases 3 Mar 1838, Ref PS/AY/P/5

title: Risborough to Thame Turnpike Completed
description: The A4129, the turnpike road from Risborough to Thame, was completed. No longer did travelers from Thame to Risborough need to travel via Towersey and Ilmer, with its damp and boggy roads.
references: Making the road from Risborough to Thame, Bucks archaeological soc

title: Cottages and Land at Lockington for Sale
description: Cottages and Land at Lockington, currently occupied by John Allen, were to be sold.

title: Moreton Frewen Inherits Property
description: Moreton John Edward Frewen succeeded his father, Dr (Rev) Edward Frewen, who had amassed a 'considerable landed property'. This included the Manor of Ilmer, however on his death the lifetime benefit of the Manor would pass to a number of women in his extended family.
references: Burke, A Genealogical and Heraldic History of the Commoners of Great Britain, 1838

title: Birth of David Goodchild
description: David Goodchild was born in Risborough.

title: William Edwards Partridge Becomes Vicar
description: William Edwards Partridge became vicar of Ilmer.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: Partridge Appointed Vicar by Earl
description: W.E. Partridge was appointed vicar by the 6th Earl of Chesterfield.

title: Wycombe Poor Law Union Formed
description: The Wycombe Poor Law Union was formed, with Ilmer as one of the founding 33 parishes.

title: Farm Occupants Recorded
description: John Eggleton Junr was at Middle House Farm and John Tapping at Upper House Farm.

title: Tithe Map Shows Middle Farm
description: The tithe map shows the existence of Middle Farm.

title: Manor Ownership Recorded
description: Moreton John Edward Frewen and Vice Admiral Henry Raper were joint owners of the manor.
references: Apportionment of the Rent Charge, Tithe Map, 26 Mar 1841

title: Marriage of Vicar W. E. Partridge
description: At Swallowfield, Berkshire, the Rev. W. E. Partridge, Vicar of Ilmer, marries Lucy-Olivia-Hobart Anderdon, only surviving child of Oliver Anderdon, esq. Q.C.

title: Partridge Becomes Owner of Horsenden Manor
description: W.E. Partridge becomes owner of Horsenden Manor.

title: Architect G.E. Street Appointed
description: The Oxford Diocese appoints the renowned ecclesiastical architect [George Edmund Street](https://www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-26659) to oversee the renovation of churches, eventually including the 'dilapidated' St. Peter's in Ilmer.

title: Population Recorded
description: The population was 82.

title: Birth of George Wooster
description: George Wooster was born to Sarah and James Wooster (farmer).

title: Church Patronage Sold
description: The church patronage was sold by George Stanhope, 6th Earl of Chesterfield to W.E. Partridge, vicar of Ilmer.
references: Victoria History of the County of Buckingham vol 4

title: Church Refurbishment
description: The church chancel was rebuilt and the nave refurbished, mostly paid for by Rev W.E. Partridge. A commemoration stone was installed on the north wall. By 1983 this stone had significantly degraded and was replaced with a like-for-like replacement

title: Restored Church Reopened
description: Following extensive restoration by G.E. Street, St. Peter's Church is formally reopened on Thursday, 30th August, by Bishop Samuel Wilberforce, just two months after his famous Oxford debate opposing Darwin's theory of evolution.

title: Church Harmonium
description: The church had a harmonium situated in the chancel adjacent to the window-seat sculptures. Later photographs show the harmonium against the south wall of the nave adjacent to the rood screen.
references: SHEHAN. Plan for 1860 commemorative stone replacement, 1983

title: Population Recorded
description: The population was 79.

title: Ilmer Manor House Occupant
description: Ilmer Manor House was in the possession of John Eggleton, farmer.

title: Lord of the Manor
description: Moreton John Edwin Frewen was the Lord of the Manor.
references: Victoria History of the County of Buckingham vol 4

title: Death of James Wooster
description: James Wooster, Farmer, dies aged 60 / 63.

title: Architect Discusses Rood Screen
description: Architect [George Edmund Street](https://www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-26659), who had overseen the church's restoration, read a paper to the Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA). He discussed the church's middle-pointed rood screen, noting its unusual stone base and suggesting it was created by the same craftsman responsible for the screen at Thame.
references: 'On English woodwork in the thirteenth and fourteenth centuries', G. E. Street, read at RIBA, 20 Feb 1865

title: Livings of Horsenden and Ilmer United
description: The Church Livings of Horsenden and Ilmer were united.

title: Death of George Stanhope, 6th Earl of Chesterfield
description: George Stanhope, 6th Earl of Chesterfield, died and had also sold Ascott House.

title: Ilmer Mentioned in Punch Magazine
description: Ilmer is mentioned in [Punch magazine](https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=V5gwAAAAYAAJ&dq=editions%3Ao0ZG0cjtFIAC&pg=PA212#v=onepage&q=Sarah%20Wooster&f=false), relating the role of Ilmer's Sarah Wooster to the women's suffrage movement.

title: Farmers and Officials Listed
description: Richard Belgrove, John Eggleton, Mrs Hannah Gomme, and Mrs Sarah Wooster are listed as farmers. Moreton John Edwin Frewen and Mrs Raper are joint lords of the manor.

title: Manor Ownership
description: Mrs Raper and Moreton John Edwin Frewen jointly held the manor.
references: Victoria History of the County of Buckingham vol 4

title: Birth of Elizabeth Mason
description: Elizabeth Mason (later Goodchild) was born. She subsequently married Albert Goodchild and Charles Keene.

title: Death of Moreton John Edward Frewen
description: Moreton John Edward Frewen died childless. Ownership of Ilmer farms transferred to his cousin, Mrs Moreton-Cragie. On Mrs Moreton-Cragie's subsequent death, the life benefit of the manor of Ilmer transferred to her sister, Elizabeth Moreton.
references: Burke's Genealogical and Heraldic History of the Landed Gentry, 1925

title: Census Data
description: The population was 70. Farm occupants included Richard and Martha Belgrove, Thomas and Mary Eggleton, and Henry and Sarah Gomm. David and Elizabeth Goodchild lived in Longwick.

title: Birth of Elizabeth Goodchild (nee Mason)
description: Elizabeth Goodchild (nee Mason) was born in Kingshill, Hughenden. She would later marry Albert Goodchild and together build Ilmer House.

title: Birth of Albert Goodchild
description: Albert Goodchild was born in Ilmer to David and Elizabeth.

title: Birth of Ernest Goodchild
description: Ernest Goodchild was born in Ilmer to David and Elizabeth.

title: Fire at Mr Read's Farm
description: A fire occurred at Mr Read's farm.

title: James Clare Enlists
description: 18 year old James Clare signed up for the Grenadier Guards, serving for 12 years.

title: Census Data
description: The population was 63. David and Elizabeth Goodchild lived in Ilmer with four children.

title: Death of Sarah Maria Clotilda Raper
description: Sarah Maria Clotilda Raper died and bequeathed part of her estate for the annual benefit of the poor. The Rapers were land-owners including the Manor of Ilmer.
references: Victoria History of the County of Buckingham vol 3

title: Upper Farm for Sale
description: Upper Farm was put up for sale with tenant Mr Belgrove, alongside Ford Farm and Aston Mullins Farm.

title: Landowners and Farmers Listed
description: Moreton John Edwin Frewen and Mrs Raper are listed as joint owners of the manor. Edwin Morris, John Read, Richard Belgrove, and Mrs Hannah Gomme are listed as farmers.

title: Death of Elizabeth Goodchild
description: Elizabeth, wife of David Goodchild, farmer, dies of 'fatty degeneration of the heart'.

title: David Goodchild at The Old Vicarage
description: David Goodchild was living at The Old Vicarage. He was the father of Albert, Ernest, and Thomas Goodchild.

title: Burial of Elizabeth Goodchild
description: Elizabeth Goodchild was buried. Elizabeth was the mother of Albert, Ernest, and Thomas Goodchild and wife of David who was to die the following year.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: Birth of Charles Belgrove
description: Charles Belgrove was born. Later in life, following a disagreement with his father, he would become known as the Ilmer Hermit.

title: Death of Rev W.E Partridge
description: Rev W.E Partridge dies aged 77, leaving an estate valued at £3,482.

title: John Ormond Becomes Rector
description: John Ormond became rector of Horsenden with Ilmer.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: John Read Retires
description: John Read, farmer, retires.

title: Death of David Goodchild
description: David Goodchild, farmer, dies of a heart attack aged 55. He was the father of Albert, Ernest, and Thomas Goodchild leaving them orphaned as his wife died the previous year.

title: Burial of David Goodchild
description: David Goodchild was buried. He was the father of Albert, Ernest, and Thomas Goodchild leaving them orphaned as his wife died the previous year.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: Lockington Freehold for Sale
description: Lockington freehold property was to be sold. Lockington is the nearby abandoned hamlet and home for many years of the Ilmer Hermit. It is now known as Hermit's Wood.

title: John Read at Manor Farm
description: Mr Read, farmer, was at Manor Farm.

title: Manor Ownership
description: General Raper and Moreton John Edwin Frewen jointly held the manor.
references: Victoria History of the County of Buckingham vol 4

title: Thomas Goodchild at The Old Vicarage
description: Thomas Goodchild was living at The Old Vicarage. He was the older brother of Albert and Ernest Goodchild.

title: Census Data
description: The population was 48. Albert Goodchild, aged 17, worked as a Gardener in Wycombe.

title: Estate Transfer
description: Mrs Moreton-Craigie died, and the estate comprising Manor Farm, Lower Farm and Coldharbour Farm transferred to her sister, Miss Elizabeth Moreton. Sister Elizabeth Moreton was a founder member of the Clewer Sisters, Community of St John the Baptist near Windsor.
references: Victoria History of the County of Buckingham vol 4
A Place in Life, Valerie Bonham, 1992

title: Church Roof Refurbishment
description: Miss Moreton agreed to pay for the refurbishment of the church roof.

title: Ernest Goodchild Emigrates
description: Ernest William Goodchild departed Liverpool for Quebec, aged 13, as part of the Children's Aid Society of London. He was the younger brother of Albert who were orphaned living in Ilmer. Their older brother, Thomas, cared for them at the Old Vicarage.
references: Board of Trade, Outwards Passenger Lists

title: Church Restoration
description: The church roof was repaired, the porch re-built, the belfry and bells rehung, a new stove installed, and an iron fence erected.

title: Restoration Work Commemorated
description: To mark the completion of the 1893 church restorations, which included roof repairs and the rehanging of the bells, the Bishop of Reading delivers a special sermon.

title: Farmers and Landowners Listed
description: Farmers listed include Richard Belgrove, Mrs Hannah Gomme, Morris Edwin, and John Read. Landowners include Moreton John Edwin Frewen and Mrs Raper.

title: George Kingham at Lower Farm
description: George Kingham was living at Lower Farm.

title: Possible Marriage of Albert Goodchild
description: Albert Goodchild possibly married Elizabeth Mason in Bromley. He had been orphaned aged 13 living in Ilmer.

title: Miss Moreton Living in Torquay
description: By 1894, Miss Elizabeth Moreton, Sister Elizabeth, owner of the Manor of Ilmer through a lifetime benefit, was living in Torquay leasing a property known as Cyprus on Ridgeway Road.

title: George Kingham Tenancy Begins
description: George Kingham's tenancy began at Lower Farm.

title: John Edwin Varley Becomes Rector
description: John Edwin Varley became rector of Horsenden with Ilmer.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: Landowners and Farmers Listed
description: General Raper and Miss Moreton are listed as principal landowners. Farmers include Richard Belgrove, George Gomme, Thomas Goodchild, Alfred Hill, and George Kingham.

title: Farm Tenancies Begin
description: Alfred Hill's tenancy began at Manor Farm and George Gomme's tenancy began at Coldharbour.

title: Albert Goodchild's Business
description: Albert Goodchild is listed as a nurseryman in Beckenham. He had been orphaned aged 13 living in Ilmer.
references: London Suburban, Kelly's Directory Vol II Pt 1 Southern, 1901

title: Census Data
description: The population was 51. Farm occupants and families are listed. Albert and Elizabeth Goodchild lived in Beckenham.

title: Charles Belgrove Emigrates
description: Charles Belgrove departs Liverpool for Quebec, destination Winnipeg. Charles soon returned, disliking the weather, and became better known as the Ilmer Hermit.
references: Board of Trade, Outwards Passenger Lists

title: Landowners and Residents Listed
description: Miss Moreton is the lady of the manor. Residents include Richard Belgrove, Thomas Goodchild, Alfred Hill, and George Kingham.

title: Death of Sarah Kingham
description: Sarah, wife of George Kingham, died aged 60.

title: Ilmer or Upper Farm for Auction
description: Ilmer or Upper Farm was put up for auction along with Ford and Aston Mullins farms. Richard Belgrove was the tenant farmer.
references: Sale particulars, in Bucks archive, D-PC/395

title: Lodge Cottages Built
description: 1 and 2 Lodge Cottages (site of Folly Cottage) were built.
references: 1989 sale particulars, Raffety Buckland & Ilmer/Upper Farm sale particulars 1905, all in Bucks Archives

title: Parish Room Opened
description: The Parish room, paid for by Miss Moreton, was opened. Sister Elizabeth Moreton, founder member of the Clewer Sisters, Community of St John the Baptist near Windsor, held life-benefit of the manor of Ilmer. She often contributed to religious causes in the village.

title: Landowners and Residents Listed
description: Miss Moreton is the lady of the manor. Residents include Daniel W Cook, Richard Belgrove, George Gomme, Thomas Goodchild, Alfred Hill, and George Kingham.

title: Albert Goodchild's Business
description: Albert Goodchild was listed as a wholesaler at the Foreign Flower market, Covent Garden, London. He would later acquire the Manor of Ilmer and build Ilmer House on the site of Upper Farm.

title: Fatal Accident at Coldharbour Farm
description: Hettie Gomm, aged 5, was accidentally shot and killed at Coldharbour farm by her brother aged 13.

title: Burial of Ettie Gomme
description: 'Ettie' Nellie Gomme, aged 5, was buried.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: Albert Goodchild's Business
description: Albert Goodchild was listed as a wholesaler at the Foreign Flower market in Covent Garden, London.

title: Ilmer Farm Auction Date
description: The auction date for 'Ilmer Farm' was set.
references: West Herts and Watford Observer, 26 Jun 1909

title: George Wooster Visits Ilmer
description: George Wooster, son of Sarah Wooster, returned to visit his birthplace of Ilmer from his home in the USA.

title: Spire Faculty Granted
description: Faculty (permission) for the new church spire was granted. Architects John Oldrid Scott and Son (Charles Marriott Oldrid Scott) of Dean's Yard, Westminster were given faculty to design the replacement spire and remove the half-hip roof to complete the west gable. John Oldrid Scott was the grandson of Sir Gilbert Scott, architect of the Albert Memorial. He had completed the stone steeple of St Mary's, Risborough the previous year, which had replaced an older zinc-covered wooden structure.

title: Ilmer House Built
description: Ilmer house was built by Albert Goodchild. Albert had acquired the Manor of Ilmer and built the house on the site of Upper Farm.

title: Spire Fundraising Concert
description: As part of the effort to raise £300 for a new spire, a packed Parish Room is the venue for a performance of a 'Sleeping Beauty' cantata.

title: Spire Fundraising
description: The spire fund needed £350, with current subscriptions totalling £190 including £100 from Miss Moreton.

title: Girls' Club Concert for Church Fund
description: The Parish Room hosts a concert by the Girls' Club in aid of the Church Restoration Fund. The children sang, danced, and performed on the violin, piano, and mandoline.

title: Vicar's Wife Holds Fundraising Recital
description: Myra Varley, wife of the vicar, gives a ticketed Elocutionary Recital in Aylesbury to help raise the remaining funds needed for the new church spire.

title: Ilmer Farm for Auction
description: 'Ilmer Farm' was put up for auction alongside Aston Mullins farm.

title: Rose Fête Raises Funds for Spire
description: A 'Rose Fête' is held at the Horsenden Rectory to raise the final £100 needed for the spire. The event, opened by [Lady Susan Trueman](https://cheshammuseum.org.uk/blogs/women-who-have-made-a-difference-locally/#:~:text=Lady%20Susan%20Trueman%2C%20O.B.E.), featured stalls, dances, races, and a Punch and Judy show, successfully raising £40.

title: Church Rededicated
description: The church was rededicated following the addition of a new Spire and completion of the west gable.

title: Albert Goodchild Purchases Upper Farm
description: Mr A Goodchild purchased Upper Farm from General Raper. Albert had been orphaned aged 13 living in Ilmer and ran a successful flower wholesale business in Covent Garden.
references: Victoria History of the County of Buckingham vol 4

title: Number of Houses in Ilmer
description: There were 12 houses in Ilmer.
references: Highways and Byways in Buckinghamshire, Shorter, 1910

title: House Plans Passed
description: Plans were passed for A Goodchild to build a house on his land in Beckenham. This was the site of his nursery on Ravenscroft Road.

title: Harry Morton Gorham Becomes Rector
description: Harry Morton Gorham became rector of Horsenden with Ilmer.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: Residents Listed
description: Miss A Phillips, George Gomme, Albert Goodchild, Thomas Goodchild, Alfred Hill, and George Kingham are listed as residents. Miss Moreton is the principal landowner.

title: Census Data
description: Census data lists residents at Manor Farm, Lower Farm, and other locations. Albert and Elizabeth Goodchild lived in Beckenham with six children.

title: Coronation Celebration
description: The parish room hosted a celebration of the coronation of George V.

title: Lockington Meadow Unsold
description: Lockington meadow remained unsold at auction.

title: Birth of Robert Merrick Harling Attenborough
description: (Robert) Merrick Harling Attenborough was born to (Robert) Harold Attenborough, future owner of Ilmer House.

title: Manor Farm for Sale
description: Manor Farm was advertised for sale.

title: Death of Miss Moreton and Estate Transfer
description: Miss Moreton died and the estate transferred to 'Mrs Carter'. Sister Elizabeth Moreton had life benefit of the manor of Ilmer and had paid for the village hall.
references: Victoria History of the County of Buckingham vol 4

title: Miss Moreton Probate
description: Probate for Miss Moreton's estate was recorded. Sister Elizabeth Moreton had life benefit of the manor of Ilmer and had paid for the village hall.

title: Estate Sale
description: Mrs Carter sold the estate: Manor and Lower Farm were purchased by Mr W Hill and Mr A A Kingham, and Coldharbour Farm was purchased by Mr A Fisher.
references: Victoria History of the County of Buckingham vol 4

title: Farm Tenancies Recorded
description: George Kingham was tenant farmer at Lower Farm and George Gomme at Coldharbour, both owned by Elizabeth Moreton.

title: Farm Auction Particulars
description: Auction particulars for Manor Farm & Lower Farm were issued.

title: Birth of (Robert) Douglas Goodchild
description: (Robert) Douglas Goodchild was born to Albert and Elizabeth Goodchild in Tulse Hill.

title: Albert Goodchild's Residence
description: Ilmer House owner, Albert Goodchild lived at 158 Ravenscroft Rd, Beckenham.

title: Manor Farm Tenancy
description: Alfred Hill was the tenant farmer at Manor Farm, owned by Elizabeth Moreton.

title: Death of Albert Lay in WWI
description: Albert Lay, aged 20, of Ilmer died in Flanders while serving in the Oxford & Bucks Light Infantry.

title: Residents Listed
description: Residents included Miss A Phillips, George Gomme, Albert Goodchild, Thomas Goodchild, Alfred Hill, and George Kingham.

title: Albert Goodchild's Nursery Business for Auction
description: Ilmer House owner, Albert Goodchild's nursery business in Beckenham, including land and plants, was put up for auction.

title: William O'Connor Becomes Rector
description: William O'Connor became rector of Horsenden with Ilmer.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: Parish Room Piano Sold
description: The parish room piano was sold for £4.

title: Thomas Goodchild Buys Land
description: Freehold land at Lockington was bought by tenant T Goodchild for £60. Thomas was the elder brother of Albert Goodchild and had looked after Albert when their parents died.

title: War Memorial Tablet Agreed
description: It was agreed to put a memorial tablet in the church.

title: War Memorial Faculty Granted
description: Faculty was granted for the war memorial.
references: Church Report - St Peter's Church, Ilmer, Report 1999, by Janet Wilson

title: War Memorial Erected
description: The Great War memorial tablet was erected.
references: Registers and Records of Ilmer Parish, Rex A Kidd

title: William Magee Tuke Becomes Rector
description: William Magee Tuke became rector of Horsenden with Ilmer.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: Census Data
description: Residents at Lower Farm, Manor Farm, and Coldharbour Farm are listed.

title: Albert Goodchild's Residence
description: Albert and Elizabeth Goodchild lived at 132 Tulse Hill. They had also built Ilmer House.

title: Farmer Fined
description: Thomas Bradshaw, farmer at Lower Farm, was fined £2 for using a carriage without a licence.

title: Death of 'Sigma'
description: Richard Samuel Downs, columnist and headteacher, also known as 'Sigma', died. He wrote a number of articles on Ilmer Church.

title: Land Ownership
description: John Philip Boddington, relative of the Boddington brewery family, owned land at Ilmer.

title: Ilmergrove Property for Sale
description: Ilmergrove, 132 Tulse Hill, London was for sale with vacant possession, suitable for a hotel. This appears to have been the primary London residence of Albert and Elizabeth Goodchild's family in addition to their Ilmer House residence. Albert had given it the name Ilmergrove almost certainly after the village.

title: Electricity Lines Proposed
description: A proposal was made to lay electricity lines to Ilmer.

title: Churchyard Footpath Diverted
description: The footpath through the churchyard was diverted.

title: Teenager Fined
description: (Robert) Douglas Goodchild, son of Albert Goodchild, aged 13, was fined 7s 6d for riding a cycle without a light.

title: Residents of Ilmer House
description: Mr & Mrs Albert Goodchild lived at Ilmer House.

title: Albert Goodchild Buys Old Vicarage
description: Albert Goodchild of Ilmer House bought the Old Vicarage.

title: Church Stove Repaired
description: The church stove was repaired.

title: Electric Lighting Offered
description: Albert Goodchild of Ilmer House offered to install electric lighting in the church and supply power.

title: Electric Lighting Faculty Granted
description: Faculty was granted to install electric lighting in the church.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: Ilmer Halt Station Opens
description: LNER station Ilmer Halt opened. It was to close in 1963.

title: Arthur Montague Berry Becomes Rector
description: Arthur Montague Berry became rector of Horsenden with Ilmer.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: W Harper Elected Church Warden
description: W Harper, father of George Harper, was elected People's Warden.

title: Motorcyclist Fined
description: (Robert) Douglas Goodchild of Ilmer House was fined 4s for having an indistinct numberplate on his motorbike.

title: (Robert) Douglas Goodchild, Nursery Student
description: (Robert) Douglas Goodchild, son of Albert Goodchild of Ilmer House, is listed as a nursery student.

title: Death of Thomas Goodchild
description: Thomas Goodchild (Farmer) dies aged 67.

title: Burial of Thomas Goodchild
description: Thomas Goodchild was buried.

title: Death of Albert Goodchild
description: Albert Goodchild, husband of Elizabeth Goodchild of Ilmer House, died aged 57.

title: Burial of Albert Goodchild
description: Albert Goodchild was buried.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: Whist Drive at Ilmer House
description: A whist drive was held at Ilmer House.

title: (Robert) Merrick Attenborough Travels to New Zealand
description: (Robert) Merrick Attenborough (son of (Robert) Harold Attenborough), aged 20, departed London for Sydney, with an onward journey to New Zealand to work in farming.

title: Death of Owen Goodchild
description: Owen Goodchild died aged 54.

title: Burial of Owen Goodchild
description: Owen Goodchild of Watlington was buried.
references: Registers and records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: Church Electric Lighting
description: Ilmer church had electric lighting, with the cost recorded as a 1931 expenditure.

title: Electricity Slot Meter Request
description: The vicar requested Aylesbury corporation install an electricity slot meter in the church.

title: Grazing Pasture Auctioned
description: Mrs Goodchild auctioned various lots of grazing pasture around Ilmer.

title: Ilmer House for Auction
description: Ilmer House up for auction with vacant possession.

title: Electricity Slot Meters Installed
description: Electricity slot meters had been installed in the church.

title: Memorial Window Commissioned
description: A meeting at the Parish Hall resolves to install a stained glass window in honour of Mary Clara Jaques (daughter of former vicar Rev. W. E. Partridge) to commemorate her charitable deeds. The window, costing £70, was crafted by Joseph Edward Nuttgens.

title: Arthur Montague Berry Ceases as Rector
description: Arthur Montague Berry ceased as rector of Horsenden with Ilmer.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: Farm Livestock Sale
description: Mr H Webber put up for sale his livestock and agricultural implements as he was leaving his farm.

title: Construction of Ilmer Nurseries Begins
description: Construction of Ilmer Nurseries by (Robert) Douglas Goodchild, son of Albert Goodchild of Ilmer House, began. The business venture was ultimately unsuccessful for Douglas.

title: Stained Glass Window Installed
description: A stained glass window by Joseph Edward Nuttgens was installed in the church nave in commemoration of Mary Clara Jaques.

title: Motorcycle Trial
description: Ilmer Lane formed part of the Putnam Cup motorcycle trial, where most competitors got stuck in the mud.

title: Man Fined for After-Hours Drinking
description: (Robert) Douglas Goodchild, youngest son of Albert and Elizabeth Goodchild, was fined £1 for consuming beer during unlicensed hours at the Six Bells, Thame.

title: (Robert) Merrick Attenborough in Play
description: R M H Attenborough, son of (Robert) Harold Attenborough, appeared in the cast of a play at Massey Agricultural College, New Zealand.

title: Death of Edward Albert Goodchild
description: Edward Albert Goodchild, second son of the late Albert Goodchild, died aged 32.

title: Burial of Edward Albert Goodchild
description: Edward Albert Goodchild of Saunderton was buried.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: Marriage of Elizabeth Goodchild
description: Elizabeth Goodchild, widow of Albert Goodchild, (nee Mason), marries Charles Keene at Epsom Registry Office.

title: William O'Connor Becomes Rector
description: William O'Connor became rector of Horsenden with Ilmer.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: (Robert) Merrick Attenborough at College
description: (Robert) Merrick Attenborough, son of (Robert) Harold Attenborough, held several positions in clubs at Massey Agricultural College.
references: The Bleat, Massey Agricultural College Students' Association, 1934

title: Charles Keene's Residence
description: Charles Keene, second husband of Elizabeth Goodchild of Ilmer House, lived at 67 Devon Road, Cheam.

title: Resident of Ilmer House
description: William White lived at Ilmer House.

title: Church Warden
description: Mrs W T White was church warden.

title: Ilmer Nurseries Expanded
description: (Robert) Douglas Goodchild (son of Albert Goodchild late of Ilmer House) built 2 further greenhouses at Ilmer Nurseries.

title: Farm Workers Advertised
description: (Robert) Maher's farm advertised for farm workers and milkers.

title: Cook Advertised
description: Mrs W White advertises for a cook at Ilmer House.

title: Land Approved for Housing
description: Approval was granted to pay for land at Ilmer for a housing site. For an unknown reason, this plan never progressed.

title: Ilmer Estate Sold
description: Mr W White of Ilmer House sold his Ilmer estate.

title: Parish Mission Room Correspondence
description: Parish correspondence and a copy of the plan of the 'Mission Room' in Ilmer from 1936-1938 are recorded.
references: Parish records held in Bucks Archive

title: (Robert) Merrick Attenborough Returns to UK
description: (Robert) Merrick Attenborough, son of (Robert) Harold Attenborough, aged 24, departed Wellington, New Zealand, bound for Southampton.

title: Hotel Contents Sold
description: Contents of Ilmergrove Hotel were sold. Prior to being a hotel, Ilmergrove Hotel in London was the private residence of Albert Goodchild late of Ilmer House. Following years operating as a hotel, and subsequently as private flats, it was razed to the ground on 16th July 1943 by a V1 bomb.

title: Ilmer House Freehold Recorded
description: Ilmer House freehold was recorded in the London Gazette.

title: Magistrate
description: Mrs Attenborough of Ilmer House sat in the Hertford division of magistrates.

title: Driver Fined
description: (Robert) Douglas Goodchild, son of Albert Goodchild late of Ilmer House, was stopped for driving without sidelights and fined £1.

title: Church Warden
description: (Robert) Harold Attenborough of Ilmer House became church warden.

title: Ilmer House Land Registry
description: Ilmer House was first recorded in the Land Registry.

title: Schedule of Church Contents
description: A schedule of Church Contents was taken.
references: [Clement Oswald Skilbeck](https://sculpture.gla.ac.uk/mapping/public/view/person.php?id=msib2_1212053007) of Bledlow, Bucks Archaeological Soc

title: Resident of Ilmer House
description: Mrs Attenborough lived at Ilmer House.

title: Parish Room Ownership Discussed
description: Ownership of the parish room was discussed.

title: Charles Belgrove Interviewed
description: Charles Belgrove, the Ilmer Hermit was interviewed and photographed by a national newspaper.

title: Church Chimney Repair
description: Approval was given to repair the church chimney.

title: Residents and Landowners Listed
description: Robert H Attenborough is the principal landowner. Claridge & Son, Wilfred Smith, Robert Maher, and Douglas Goodchild are also listed.

title: Keene Family Residence
description: Elizabeth (widow of Albert Goodchild late of Ilmer House) and Charles Keene live at 67 Devon Road, Cheam, London.

title: Death of Elizabeth Kingham
description: Elizabeth, wife of William Kingham, died age 76.

title: Bankruptcy Court Appearance
description: (Robert) Douglas Goodchild of Old Vicarage appeared at the Aylesbury Bankruptcy Court regarding his business, Ilmer Nurseries.

title: A. Goodchild Ltd Incorporated
description: 'A. Goodchild Ltd' was incorporated with Jack Goodchild as director. The Covent Garden flower wholesaler, founded by Albert Goodchild of Ilmer House, traded for many years until it was finally disolved in 2021.

title: Parish Hall Redecorated
description: Ilmer Parish Hall, also known as the Mission Room, was redecorated by Frank Rogers of Longwick. The exterior was painted green and the interior white
references: Receipt for work, parish records in Bucks archive

title: Ilmer Nurseries for Sale
description: Ilmer Nurseries and Brick Pits Cottage were put up for sale.

title: Farmer Prosecuted
description: Claridge & Son of Lower Farm were prosecuted for selling watered-down milk.

title: Cowman Wage Complaint
description: R.M.H Attenborough complained that the minimum wage for a cowman in Bucks was higher than in Herts.

title: Help Advertised for Sick Bay
description: Mrs Attenborough advertised for help with Ilmer House sick bay for children.

title: Invasion Preparations
description: The vestry was informed of local arrangements in the event of an invasion, including using the Church Room as a mortuary.

title: Soldiers Use Church Room
description: Seven soldiers had slept in the Church Room for one night.

title: Fatality at Ilmer Halt
description: Thomas Walker, a railway worker, was found dead on the platform of Ilmer Halt after being hit by a train.
references: GW & GC Joint Railway accident report, national archives

title: Marriage of (Robert) Merrick Attenborough
description: (Robert) Merrick Attenborough, son of (Robert) Harold Attenborough, married Anne Elizabeth "Betty" Wheelwright. Betty was a children's nurse at Ilmer House and had discovered the body of Thomas Walker on the Halt in 1944

title: William O'Connor Ceases as Rector
description: William O'Connor ceased as rector of Horsenden with Ilmer.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: Church Walls Repaired
description: Cracks that had appeared in the north and south walls of the church were repaired.

title: Longwick Becomes Independent Parish
description: Longwick became an independent parish.
references: Stanley Freese 1946 The Windmills and Watermills of Buckinghamshire

title: Edmund Pipe Becomes Rector
description: Edmund Walter Samuel Pipe became rector of Horsenden with Ilmer.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: Old Vicarage Sold
description: Elizabeth Keene (widow of Albert Goodchild) sold the Old Vicarage where her son (Robert) Douglas Goodchild had been living.

title: Dudley Leuw Runs Ilmer Nurseries
description: Dudley Scales Leuw began running Ilmer Nurseries. He eventually retired in 1969 and lived to the age of 100.

title: Folk Dance at Ilmer House
description: A folk dance was held at Ilmer House, hosted by Mr & Mrs Attenborough.

title: The Rosary for Auction
description: The Rosary property was put up for auction.

title: Death of Charles Keene
description: Charles Keene, second husband of Elizabeth Goodchild of Ilmer House, died aged 76.

title: Manor Farm Cottage Built
description: Manor Farm Cottage was built.

title: Eviction of Tenants
description: (Robert) Merrick Attenborough successfully applied for the eviction of the tenants of Lodge Cottage and Ilmer Cottage.

title: Church Fundraising Bazaar
description: A bazaar at Longwick Schoolroom raised £65 for Ilmer church.

title: Land Registry Entry
description: 1 The Green appears on the Land Registry.

title: Farms Registered
description: Lower and Bumpers farms were registered in HM land registry by Claridge.

title: Farmer Information
description: W J Claridge farmed Lower Farm for 27 years and was chairman of the NFU.

title: New Carpet Fitted
description: A new carpet was fitted in the church for the sum of £19-1-3.

title: Puppy Show
description: A puppy show was held at Close End, residence of (Robert) Merrick Attenborough

title: Marriage of (Annie) Mavis Attenborough
description: (Annie) Mavis Attenborough, daughter of (Robert) Harold Attenborough of Ilmer House, married (Stanley) Frank Head.

title: Churchyard Cleared
description: Les Bailey, an employee of Mr Attenborough, cleared the overgrown churchyard and laid a path.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: ShellStar Purchases Lower Farm
description: Lower Farm was purchased by ShellStar.

title: Farm Manager Appointed
description: R.T.R Pierce was appointed manager of the ShellStar demonstration farm.

title: ShellStar Centre Approved
description: Planning was approved to erect a ShellStar lecture & demonstration centre at Lower Farm.

title: Death of Elizabeth Keene
description: Elizabeth Keene, widow of Albert Goodchild of Ilmer House died.

title: Blaster Bates at ShellStar Site
description: Blaster Bates blew tree stumps out of the ground to make way for the ShellStar demonstration centre.
references: Recollection of Les Lane of 2 The Green

title: Ilmer Halt Closes
description: Ilmer Halt station is closed. It had only been open for 34 years.

title: New Church Altar Frontal
description: A new church altar frontal was paid for with a £100 donation from Shell Farm.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: Cattle Auction
description: Manor Farm Ilmer Herd held an auction of 163 cattle.

title: Oak Communion Rail Added
description: An oak communion rail, made by Ivor Newton of Haddenham, was added to the church.
references: Registers and Records of Ilmer Parish, Rex A Kidd
Church Report - St Peter's Church, Ilmer, Report 1999, by Janet Wilson

title: Death of William Joseph Harper
description: William Joseph Harper died. He lived at 1 Central Cottage in Longwick and was the father of George Harper.

title: Theft Conviction
description: June Tillman of 1 The Green pleaded guilty to stealing petty cash from Dudley Leuw of The Old Vicarage.

title: Donation from Filming
description: The church received £50 from filming, believed to be Chitty Chitty Bang Bang.
references: Barclays Bank account book, Bucks Archives

title: Donation from Chitty Chitty Bang Bang Filming
description: The church received a donation of £250 from Shell Farm, from the filming of [Chitty Chitty Bang Bang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chitty_Chitty_Bang_Bang).
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: Old Orchard Built
description: The house Old Orchard was built. The land was a wedding gift from (Robert) Harold Attenborough to his daughter Mavis.

title: Ilmer on Magazine Cover
description: Ilmer Church and the old vicarage featured on the cover of Bucks Life magazine.

title: Sale of Ilmer House
description: Ilmer House was sold by (Robert) Merrick Attenborough to William Greaves Underwood and his then-wife Susan. Susan later re-married and died in 2025.

title: Church Refurbishment by Parishioners
description: Redecoration and reconstruction work on the church, costing £1,000, is carried out and funded by the parishioners.

title: Residents of Ilmer House
description: William Greaves Underwood's parents-in-law, Alan Philip Lloyd Cogswell, known as Coggie and Mrs (Audrey) Sylvia Cogswell, known as Dum, lived at Ilmer House. Alan was an anaesthetist and lawyer, whilst Sylvia was an expert and author in orthoptics under her maiden name of Jackson.

title: Death of Sarah Olive Leuw
description: Sarah Olive Leuw, mother of Dudley Scales Leuw of The Old Vicarage died.

title: Service for Sarah Olive Leuw
description: A service was held at Ilmer Church for Sarah Olive Leuw, aged 95.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: Death of (Robert) Harold Attenborough
description: (Robert) Harold Attenborough of Ilmer House dies aged 88.
references: Parish registers and records, transcribed by Rex A Kidd

title: Death of Charles Belgrove
description: Charles Belgrove, the Ilmer Hermit, dies aged 84 in Lockington.

title: Burial of Charles Belgrove
description: Charles Belgrove, the Ilmer Hermit, was buried.

title: Edmund Pipe Ceases as Rector
description: Edmund Walter Samuel Pipe ceased as rector of Horsenden with Ilmer.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: Wooden Angels Installed in Church
description: Faculty was granted for the installation of 16th-century wooden angels in memory of (Robert) Harold Attenborough.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: (Robert) Merrick Attenborough Retires as Pack Master
description: (Robert) Merrick Attenborough, pack master since 1957, retired from the role. Merrick farmed Manor Farm and lived at Close End.

title: Dudley Scales Leuw Sells Ilmer Nurseries
description: Dudley Scales Leuw sold Ilmer Nurseries. He moved to the West Midlands and lived to the age of 100.

title: Jim Lawrence Takes Over Ilmer Nurseries
description: Jim Lawrence took over running Ilmer Nurseries from Dudley Scales Leuw.

title: First Ilmer Church History Leaflet
description: The first community history leaflet of Ilmer Church was written by Dudley Scales Leuw. It was subsequently updated by Janet Wilson.

title: Charles Belgrove Official Date of Death
description: The Ilmer Hermit, Charles Belgrove's official date of death is recorded.

title: Manor Farm for Sale
description: Manor Farm, consisting of 302 acres and 4 cottages, was put up for sale.
references: Sale particulars, Jackson Stops property, Historic England Archive

title: William Hugh Jones Becomes Rector
description: William Hugh Jones became rector of Princes Risborough with Ilmer.
references: Registers and Records of St Peters, Rex Kidd, Dec 1982

title: Farm Manager
description: John A. Farmer was the manager of the ShellStar demonstration farm, Lower Farm.

title: Manor Farm Sold
description: Manor Farm was sold after auction.

title: Farmhouse Plans Approved
description: Plans were approved to build a farmhouse at Manor Farm.

title: Church Hall Sold
description: The Church Hall was sold to J Pryor of the old vicarage for £300.

title: Bankruptcy Notice
description: Paul Richard Hall of 'The Caravan, The Rosery, Ilmer' received a bankruptcy notice.

title: Notable resident
description:
[Sir William Willatt Slack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Slack_(surgeon)), Willie to friends and his wife [Lady Joan](https://history.rcplondon.ac.uk/inspiring-physicians/lady-joan-slack) (half-sister to Betty Attenborough) had a weekend retreat at Ilmer Cottage (now September/October cottages). He was the Queen's Surgeon between 1975 and 1990, being promoted to Serjeant Surgeon to Her Majesty the Queen in 1983. His Obituary in the Times, said 
 > Sir William and his wife Lady Joan, bought a country cottage where, no sooner had they arrived for the weekend, Slack could be seen tilling their acre of ground no matter what the time or weather. He grew far too many potatoes, leeks, courgettes and other vegetables for the family to eat, so the excess was distributed to friends and neighbours by the barrowload.

title: Death of Alan Philip Lloyd Cogswell
description: Alan Philip Lloyd Cogswell of Ilmer House died.

title: ShellStar Office Extension Approved
description: Approval was granted to extend the ShellStar office building in the grounds of Lower Farm.

title: Eton College Buys Manor Farm
description: Eton College bought Manor Farm from Benjamin Smith.

title: Parish Room Demolished
description: The wooden Parish Room, which had been donated by Miss Moreton in 1907 and served as a village hall and meeting space, is demolished. It had been purchased by J Pryor of the Old Vicarage in 1971.

title: Tennis Court Construction Approved
description: Planning approval was granted for the construction of a tennis court opposite 'Ilmer Cottage'. The cottage is now known as September and October Cottages.

title: Church Masonry Repair
description: Masonry repair was carried out on the church.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: Lightning Conductor Repaired
description: The church lightning conductor was repaired.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: Spire and Bell Restoration Fund
description: A fundraising campaign is initiated to raise £8,000 as the spire required new shingle tiles and the tower and bells were in need of restoration. The target was met within two years.

title: Ilmer Flower Festival
description: The Ilmer flower festival raised £250 for the Church Restoration Fund.
references: Flower festival scrapbook & letter from Rector, Ilmer church

title: Donation from Shell Farm
description: The church restoration fund received £200 from Shell Farm, now Lower Farm.

title: Number of Households
description: Ilmer had 16 householders.

title: First Ilmer Grand Fete
description: The first Ilmer Grand Fete was held.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: Plant Sale at Ilmer House
description: A plant sale was held at Ilmer House, organised by Mrs Cogswell.

title: Church Fundraising Whist Drive
description: Mollie Shurrock held a whist drive in aid of the church restoration fund.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: Church Repairs Certificate
description: An Archdeacons' certificate was granted for repairs to the bells, turret, and tower timber frame.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: Church Spire Re-shingled
description: The church spire was re-shingled from donations totalling £8,000.

title: Residents Leave Ilmer
description: Mr J & Mrs Molly Shurrock, cowman and residents of Manor Farm, left Ilmer to live in Bledlow. Mrs Shurrock had rented the Church Close land where she kept goats, calves and sheep.

title: Engagement Announcement
description: Joanna Hadwen Attenborough, daughter of Merrick of Close End, was engaged to Nicholas Palmer Kyle Montgomery.

title: Church Pews Repaired
description: Faculty was granted for the repair of church pews.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: Declaration of Diocesan Interest in Land
description: A declaration of Diocesan interest was made in 1.9 acres of freehold land at Church Close, for the repairs of St Peters, Ilmer.

title: Altar Linen Embroidered
description: Altar linen was embroidered with IHS by Betty Attenborough of Close End.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: Death of (Robert) Douglas Goodchild
description: (Robert) Douglas Goodchild died aged 68 in Letchworth, Herts.

title: Bells Restored and Re-hung
description: The church bells were restored by Whites of Appleton and re-hung.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: Church Stonework Repaired
description: The church stonework was repaired.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: Shellstar Sells Equipment
description: Shellstar began selling off equipment from Lower Farm.

title: Commemoration Stone Replaced
description: The commemoration stone on the church's north wall was replaced.

title: First Village Fete at Skipworths Farm
description: The first village fete was held in the grounds of Skipworths farm.

title: Shellstar Sells Lower Farm
description: Shellstar sold Lower Farm, which included Bumpers and the remains of Coldharbour farm.

title: Ilmer Nurseries Clearance Auction
description: A clearance auction was held for Ilmer Nurseries.

title: Church Fund Renamed
description: The Ilmer Church restoration fund was renamed to the preservation fund.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: Ilmer House for Sale
description: Ilmer House was put up for sale.

title: Church Roof Gale Damage
description: The church roof suffered gale damage and was repaired under insurance.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: NADFAS Church Record
description: A NADFAS (National Association of Decorative & Fine Arts Societies) church record was created.

title: Last Ilmer Fete
description: The last Ilmer fete was held.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: Death of Charles Henry Mardell MBE
description: Charles Henry Mardell MBE died. A plaque is in the churchyard. His connection to Ilmer is unknown.

title: New Dwellings Approved
description: The Builders' Yard received approval to erect 2 new dwellings - The Sidings and Bridge House.

title: Sunrise 'Back to the future' Rave
description: The Sunrise 'Back to the future' acid house dance festival was held in fields east of Ilmer, with 15,000 attendees. For the party goers, it became the stuff of legend.
references: Rave New World, Kirk Field, Nine Eight Books, 2023

title: Keir Starmer on Kilroy
description: Keir Starmer, future prime minister, appeared on TV talk-show "Kilroy" about rave culture, representing the National Council for Civil Liberties.

title: Lodge Cottages for Sale
description: 1 & 2 Lodge Cottages and 6 acres of adjoining pasture were put up for sale by auction.
references: Raffety Buckland, 1989, Sale particulars. Copy in Bucks archive

title: Church Acquisitions
description: New church altar linen, a new organ, and an offertory box were installed.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: Companies Relocate from ShellStar Buildings
description: Goran Plastics and Broshuis Trailers left the old ShellStar buildings and relocated.

title: New Altar Frontal
description: A new purple church altar frontal cloth was purchased.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: ShellStar Office Demolition Approved
description: Approval was granted to demolish the former ShellStar office building and erect a 'private display building'.

title: Folly Cottage Erection Approved
description: Planning approval was granted for the demolition of the semi-detached cottages known as Lodge Cottages and erection of Folly Cottage.

title: New Stained Glass Window
description: Joseph Ambrose Nuttgens created the window on the south side of the Church, a gift from an anonymous resident of Longwick.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: Bankruptcy Order
description: Roger Slade of Ilmer House received a bankruptcy order.

title: Barn Dance
description: A barn dance was held in a dutch barn.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: Shellstar Offices Demolished
description: The Shellstar offices were demolished. The site is now a private museum.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: Church Stonework Restored
description: The church stonework was restored.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: Font Cover Base Replaced
description: The base of the octagonal font cover was replaced with 19th-century oak.
references: Church Report - St Peter's Church, Ilmer, Report 1999, by Janet Wilson

title: Bankruptcy Order
description: Arthur John Hook of Close End received a bankruptcy order.

title: 'Photographing Fairies' Filmed
description: The film '[Photographing Fairies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Photographing_Fairies)' was shot in the churchyard. The church received a £500 donation.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: New Green Altar Frontal
description: A new green church altar frontal was purchased using a donation in memory of Winifred Gomme.
references: St Peter's Church, Ilmer, History and Events, Janet Wilson, 1999

title: Church Report Published
description: A report on St Peter's Church, Ilmer, was published by Janet Wilson.

title: Death of (Annie) Mavis Head

title: Death of (Stanley) Frank Head
description: (Stanley) Frank Head, resident of Old Orchard, died and is buried in Ilmer churchyard.

title: Death of Betty Attenborough
description: Betty Attenborough, wife of Merrick, late of Close End, died.
references: Wheelwright family book, Wheelwright Genealogy (S Plummer)

title: Lectern and Pews Restored
description: The lectern and pews were restored.

title: Parish Records Archived
description: The parish council agreed to archive parish records at the County Archive.
references: Minutes of the Parish Council Meeting, 18 Aug 2009

title: Death of (Robert) Merrick Attenborough
description: (Robert) Merrick Attenborough, former resident, farmer of Manor Farm and resident of Close End died.

title: Bankruptcy Order
description: Benjamin Karl Lovelock, a window cleaner of Ilmer Meadows, received a bankruptcy order.

title: Church Recordings Updated
description: Church Recordings (formerly NADFAS) were updated.

title: Bankruptcy Order
description: Graham Harold Eden of Ilmer Meadows received a bankruptcy order.

title: Death of George Harper
description: George Harper, churchwarden, parish council chair and longtime resident died.

title: Death of Nicholas Parsons
description: [Nicholas Parsons](https://www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-90000381685), actor, TV and radio presenter, and resident of Ilmer died.

title: Death of William Greaves Underwood
description: William Greaves Underwood, late of Ilmer House, died in Brill.
